== Early life ==

sentences: Early life ==
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Lane was born Eleanor Johnston in Peoria, Illinois to Andrew and Pansy Johnston.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: She was one of 12 children born into the family.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: The Johnston family lived in a two-bedroom home located in the nearby town of East Peoria, Illinois.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: She was given the nickname, "Ellie", by her father at an early age and was called it throughout her early years.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: During her childhood, Ellie developed an interest with the family's kitchen radio, which often played soap operas and popular songs of the era.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: During her school-aged years, she took a specialized course for a speech impediment that she had developed as a young child.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Ellie was often bullied in school for her lisp and her small stature.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: She eventually graduated from East Peoria High School in the late 1950s.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: She was introduced to country music from her husband, Lee Stoller, whom she met in her late teens.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Her first country music artists of interest were Eddy Arnold, Jim Reeves and Marty Robbins.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: After marrying, the Stollers moved into an apartment in East Peoria before buying a converted garage in the same area with a 50-dollar per-month mortgage.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: The couple soon had three children by 1964.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Now known as Ellie Stoller, she took employment at a printing company in East Peoria, while her husband was employed as a salesmen with Pepperidge Farms.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: In 1965, Stoller overheard his wife singing Patti Page's "Tennessee Waltz" and was impressed by her voice.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: From then on, it was Stoller's idea that she could become a country music singing star and began encouraging her to perform in front of people.
section: == Early life ==

section: == Career == | === 1982–present: Christian music transition and slowing down ===

sentences: It was followed by a re-recorded patriotic salute to Vietnam veterans in 1986.
section: == Career == | === 1982–present: Christian music transition and slowing down ===

sentences: Her final album with Liberty was the holiday-themed White Christmas in 1987.
section: == Career == | === 1982–present: Christian music transition and slowing down ===

sentences: In the late 1980s, Lane recorded exclusively for LS Records.
section: == Career == | === 1982–present: Christian music transition and slowing down ===

sentences: In 1987, a pair of singles released on the label reached minor Billboard country chart positions, including a cover of "He's Got the Whole World in His Hands".
section: == Career == | === 1982–present: Christian music transition and slowing down ===

sentences: The label released Lane's next studio album in 1988 titled All in His Hands.
section: == Career == | === 1982–present: Christian music transition and slowing down ===

sentences: The record was sold on television and was a collection of more Christian material.
section: == Career == | === 1982–present: Christian music transition and slowing down ===

sentences: It was followed by an album of secular cover tunes in 1991.
section: == Career == | === 1982–present: Christian music transition and slowing down ===

sentences: Transitioning into the 1990s, Lane and Stoller opened the "Cristy Lane Theater" in Branson, Missouri.
section: == Career == | === 1982–present: Christian music transition and slowing down ===

sentences: Lane was among the first country artists to use Branson as a tourist attraction to Nashville music fans.
section: == Career == | === 1982–present: Christian music transition and slowing down ===

sentences: Lane's theater was also used as a way to introduce up-and-coming music acts.
section: == Career == | === 1982–present: Christian music transition and slowing down ===

sentences: The theater was sold after Lane fell of the stage in 1995 and injured her leg.
section: == Career == | === 1982–present: Christian music transition and slowing down ===

sentences: With the introduction of the world wide web in the late 1990s, Lane and Stoller started selling her music through an official website.
section: == Career == | === 1982–present: Christian music transition and slowing down ===

sentences: Previously-recorded Christian songs were re-packaged into various compilations by Lane during this time This proved successful when her 2003 compilation, One Day
section: == Career == | === 1982–present: Christian music transition and slowing down ===

sentences: At A Time: 22 All Time Favorites Vol. I & II, was her first since 1983 to reach the country albums chart, peaking at number 62.
section: == Career == | === 1982–present: Christian music transition and slowing down ===

sentences: In August 2003, she was honored by the Veterans of Foreign Wars in San Antonio, Texas for her recognition to the military, and was inducted into its hall of fame.
section: == Career == | === 1982–present: Christian music transition and slowing down ===

sentences: Lane was the first female country performer to be inducted into their hall of fame.
section: == Career == | === 1982–present: Christian music transition and slowing down ===

sentences: Plans were also laid during this period to film a biopic of Lane's life story, however, it has yet to be produced.
